questions.promptMd: You’re proposing a process change to a skeptical team. Which combination of levers is MOST appropriate to start momentum without harming trust?
questions.rationaleMd: Tests ability to select levers aligned to ethics and context rather than stacking manipulative cues.

answers.contentMd: Reciprocity (share a time‑saving template) + Commitment (pilot sign‑up)
answers.feedbackMd: Correct. Give value first and invite a small, aligned commitment.
Looks manipulative and may backfire with skeptics.
Weak signals; anonymous quotes lack credibility; humor can misfire.
Unfounded urgency erodes trust without substantive value.

questions.promptMd: True or False: Combining three or more persuasion levers in one message generally increases effectiveness.
questions.rationaleMd: Encourages disciplined, ethical design instead of shotgun tactics.

answers.feedbackMd: Over‑stacking looks coercive; select 1–2 levers matched to the audience and context.
Correct. Focus improves authenticity and clarity.

questions.promptMd: Which scenario BEST fits ethical use of authority as a lever?
questions.rationaleMd: Differentiates credential signaling from appeal to irrelevant authority.

answers.contentMd: Citing a recognized auditor’s certification relevant to the decision
Quoting a famous CEO unrelated to the domain
answers.feedbackMd: Irrelevant authority doesn’t add diagnostic value.

answers.contentMd: Referencing your own seniority without evidence
Saying "trust me" and asking to skip due diligence

questions.promptMd: True or False: Scarcity should be used only when constraints are real, explained, and beneficial to disclose.

answers.feedbackMd: Correct. Fabricated scarcity damages credibility long‑term.
Artificial scarcity is manipulative and risky.
